67741.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence SN18.3 shows it as a section within the Rāhulasaṃyutta. It is a compound meaning "consciousness sutta" or "sutta on consciousness". The form in the context is "viññāṇasuttaṃ" in the nominative singular neuter.

2754.meaning_1: Sutta on the underlying tendency to lust
2754.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Refers to the sutta (SN12.64) discussing the underlying tendency (anusaya) to lust. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "atthi" (existence, underlying tendency) modifies "rāgasutta" (sutta on lust).

35420.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence "nidānasaṃyuttaṃ, nagarasuttaṃ" identifies this as the title of a sūtra (discourse) within the Nidāna Saṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. It is a compound of nagara (city) and sutta (sūtra/discourse).

1371.construction: adhi > adhy > ajjh + ā + √vas > vus + ta
1371.phonetic:
dhi > dhy > jjh
a > u (sk ṛ)
st > tth
1371.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.65), 'ajjhāvutthaṃ' describes an ancient city inhabited by people in the past. It functions as a past participle meaning 'inhabited' or 'occupied', modifying 'nagaraṃ' (city) and agreeing with it in case (accusative singular). The literal meaning 'lived over' reflects the prefix 'adhi' (over) combined with the root 'vas' (to dwell).
1371.example_1: so tamanugaccheyya. tamanugacchanto passeyya purāṇaṃ nagaraṃ purāṇaṃ rājadhāniṃ pubbakehi manussehi ajjhāvuṭṭhaṃ [ajjhāvutthaṃ] ārāmasampannaṃ vanasampannaṃ pokkharaṇīsampannaṃ uddhāpavantaṃ [uddāpavantaṃ] ramaṇīyaṃ. atha kho so, bhikkhave, puriso rañño vā rājamahāmattassa vā āroceyya, yagghe, bhante, jāneyyāsi, ahaṃ addasaṃ araññe pavane caramāno purāṇaṃ maggaṃ purāṇañjasaṃ pubbakehi manussehi anuyātaṃ tamanugacchiṃ.

60780.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Context: Nidānasaṃyuttaṃ, sammasasuttaṃ. The word appears in the context of Saṃyutta Nikāya 12, which deals with dependent origination and related themes. Sammasasutta likely refers to a sutta about reflection or examination (sammasati). The dictionary entry classifies it as a neuter kammadhāraya compound.

15699.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (sn12.66:4.5), upadhisamudaya refers to the origin of attachments (upadhi), which is a core concept in the analysis of dependent origination. It is paired with upadhi (attachment), upadhinirodha (cessation of attachment), and the path leading to that cessation. The compound structure clearly signifies "the arising/origin of attachment".
15699.sutta_1: so upadhiñca pajānāti upadhisamudayañca pajānāti upadhinirodhañca pajānāti yā ca upadhinirodhasāruppagāminī paṭipadā tañca pajānāti.
15699.example_1: They understand attachments, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.

64366.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence, the word appears as "surāpipāsitā" (nom./voc. sg.), which is a variant spelling or a different derivation (surā + pipāsita + ā). The meaning "thirst for a drink" fits the context of a man experiencing thirst after drinking liquor.
64366.example_1: pivato hi kho taṃ chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana tatonidānaṃ maraṇaṃ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṃ vā dukkhanti. atha kho, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa evamassa, sakkā kho me ayaṃ surāpipāsitā [surāpipāsā (?)] pānīyena vā vinetuṃ dadhimaṇḍakena vā vinetuṃ bhaṭṭhaloṇikāya [maṭṭhaloṇikāya] vā vinetuṃ loṇasovīrakena vā vinetuṃ, na tvevāhaṃ taṃ piveyyaṃ, yaṃ mama assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyāti. so taṃ āpānīyakaṃsaṃ paṭisaṅkhā na piveyya, paṭinissajjeyya.

36005.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
Refers to a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12.67) where the Buddha uses the simile of a reed bundle to explain dependent origination.

51683.meaning_1: name of an arahant monk; great disciple of the Buddha; foremost disciple in analytical understanding
51683.family_set: names of monks; names of arahants; great disciples
51683.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.67), the form is mahākoṭṭhiko (nom. sg.), which is the standard declined form of mahākoṭṭhita. The text also provides a variant reading mahākoṭṭhito. The name refers to Āyasmā Mahākoṭṭhika, a chief disciple of the Buddha known for his wisdom (paññāya).
51683.example_1: 67. ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca sāriputto āyasmā ca mahākoṭṭhiko [mahākoṭṭhito] bārāṇasiyaṃ viharanti isipatane migadāye. atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.

54049.meaning_1: how eloquently expressed; how well articulated
54049.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of SN12.67, 'yāvasubhāsitaṃ' functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'how eloquently' or 'how well articulated'. It modifies the verb 'bhāsitaṃ' (spoken) and expresses the manner or degree of the speech by the elder Sāriputta.
54049.example_1: acchariyaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, abbhutaṃ, āvuso sāriputta! yāvasubhāsitaṃ cidaṃ āyasmatā sāriputtena. idañca pana mayaṃ āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ imehi chattiṃsāya vatthūhi anumodāma, jarāmaraṇassa ce, āvuso, bhikkhu nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya dhammaṃ deseti, dhammakathiko bhikkhūti alaṃ vacanāya.

23177.meaning_1: discourse to the people of Kosambī; Kosambī discourse
23177.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
A compound referring to a specific discourse (SN12.68) within the Nidānasaṃyutta, the "Connected Discourses on Causation". The headword appears to be a locative singular form in the contextual sentence. The lemma is given as the stem/nominative form.

53151.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.68), "musila" (variant reading: mūsilo, musīlo) is the name of a monk being addressed in the vocative case ("āvuso musila"). The word appears in a dialogue where the monk Musila is asked if he has direct knowledge of the principle of dependent origination (idappaccayatā) without relying on faith, preference, tradition, reasoning, or contemplation. The entry correctly identifies it as a masculine name. The lemma_1 is given as the base form without the nominative singular ending, consistent with Pāḷi dictionary conventions for proper names.
53151.example_1: 68. ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca musilo [mūsilo, musīlo] āyasmā ca paviṭṭho [saviṭṭho] āyasmā ca nārado āyasmā ca ānando kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme. atha kho āyasmā paviṭṭho āyasmantaṃ musilaṃ etadavoca, aññatreva, āvuso musila, saddhāya aññatra ruciyā aññatra anussavā aññatra ākāraparivitakkā aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā atthāyasmato musilassa paccattameva ñāṇaṃ, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti?

53065.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN12.68), 'musīla' (or variant 'musīlo') appears as a proper name of a monk. The sentence lists several monks, including 'āyasmā ca musilo [mūsilo, musīlo]', indicating a proper name for a monk, not a common noun. The variants show phonetic uncertainty. The meaning is strictly a personal name in this Buddhist textual context.
53065.example_1: 68. ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca musilo [mūsilo, musīlo] āyasmā ca paviṭṭho [saviṭṭho] āyasmā ca nārado āyasmā ca ānando kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme. atha kho āyasmā paviṭṭho āyasmantaṃ musilaṃ etadavoca, aññatreva, āvuso musila, saddhāya aññatra ruciyā aññatra anussavā aññatra ākāraparivitakkā aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā atthāyasmato musilassa paccattameva ñāṇaṃ, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti?

61339.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence SN12.68 clarifies that the original text has both "paviṭṭho" and "saviṭṭho" listed as monks, with "saviṭṭho" being the correct form for the dictionary entry. The word is a proper name, specifically for a monk, and is not derived from a verbal root. The Sanskrit cognate śraviṣṭha suggests a possible etymological connection to "śru" (to hear), but the Pāḷi dictionary entry is primarily concerned with the name as used in the suttas.
61339.example_1: 68. ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca musilo [mūsilo, musīlo] āyasmā ca paviṭṭho [saviṭṭho] āyasmā ca nārado āyasmā ca ānando kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme. atha kho āyasmā paviṭṭho āyasmantaṃ musilaṃ etadavoca, aññatreva, āvuso musila, saddhāya aññatra ruciyā aññatra anussavā aññatra ākāraparivitakkā aññatra diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā atthāyasmato musilassa paccattameva ñāṇaṃ, jātipaccayā jarāmaraṇanti?

36503.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the provided context, 'nārado' is in the nominative singular, referring to a specific monk named Nārada. The dictionary entry correctly identifies this as a masculine noun and a proper name for a monk.
36503.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca musilo āyasmā ca paviṭṭho āyasmā ca nārado āyasmā ca ānando kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
36503.example_1: At one time the venerables Musīla, Saviṭṭha, Nārada, and Ānanda were staying near Kosambī in Ghosita’s monastery.

14901.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The compound udakavāraka is listed as a bahuvrīhi compound in the related entries (e.g., udakaṭṭha). It functions as a noun in the sentence, meaning a bucket for water. The pattern is consistent with masculine nouns ending in -a.
14901.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, āvuso, kantāramagge udapāno, tatra nevassa rajju na udakavārako.
14901.example_1: Suppose there was a well on a desert road that had neither rope nor bucket.

15942.meaning_1: sutta about attaining; sutta about arrival
15942.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Nidānasaṃyutta (SN 12). The compound suggests it deals with the arising or attainment of something, likely related to dependent origination (paṭiccasamuppāda) given its context in SN 12. The form "upayantisuttaṃ" is the nominative singular neuter.

15941.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence uses 'upayanto' (nom. sg. masc.) and 'upayantiyo' (nom. pl. fem.) to describe waters (nādiyo) that are 'surging' or 'flowing towards' (the ocean). This participle captures the dynamic movement of water bodies converging.
15941.sutta_1: “mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, upayanto mahānadiyo upayāpeti, mahānadiyo upayantiyo kunnadiyo upayāpenti, kunnadiyo upayantiyo mahāsobbhe upayāpenti, mahāsobbhā upayantā kusobbhe upayāpenti.
15941.example_1: “Mendicants, when the ocean surges it makes the rivers surge. When the rivers surge they make the streams surge. When the streams surge they make the lakes surge. When the lakes surge they make the ponds surge.

15950.meaning_1: (of water) causes to flow; makes surge
15950.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence (SN 12.69), 'upayāpeti' is used in a hydrological metaphor: the ocean 'causes to surge/make surge' the rivers, streams, lakes, and ponds. It describes a causative action of water bodies causing other water bodies to swell or flow. The meaning extends beyond literal 'going near' to a dynamic process of water propagation, emphasizing the interconnectedness of natural water systems.
15950.sutta_1: “mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, upayanto mahānadiyo upayāpeti, mahānadiyo upayantiyo kunnadiyo upayāpenti, kunnadiyo upayantiyo mahāsobbhe upayāpenti, mahāsobbhā upayantā kusobbhe upayāpenti.
15950.example_1: “Mendicants, when the ocean surges it makes the rivers surge. When the rivers surge they make the streams surge. When the streams surge they make the lakes surge. When the lakes surge they make the ponds surge.

6255.meaning_1: makes recede; causes to retreat; avoids; does not associate with
6255.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the context of the provided sentence (sn12.69:2.1), the verb is used transitively with an accusative object (mahānadiyo, kunnadiyo, etc.) meaning "causes to recede/retreat." The meaning extends from the literal physical movement of water bodies to a more abstract sense of avoidance or non-association in other contexts (e.g., apayāpetabba).
6255.sutta_1: mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, apayanto mahānadiyo apayāpeti, mahānadiyo apayantiyo kunnadiyo apayāpenti, kunnadiyo apayantiyo mahāsobbhe apayāpenti, mahāsobbhā apayantā kusobbhe apayāpenti.
6255.example_1: When the ocean recedes it makes the rivers recede. When the rivers recede they make the streams recede. When the streams recede they make the lakes recede. When the lakes recede they make the ponds recede.

9533.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
The contextual sentence 'imesañca dhammānaṃ asamāpatti' means 'non-attainment of these dhammas', indicating a state or abstract quality of not attaining specific meditative states or insights. The word functions as a feminine abstract noun derived by negating 'samāpatti'.
9533.sutta_1: “ettha dāni āyasmanto idañca veyyākaraṇaṃ imesañca dhammānaṃ asamāpatti; idaṃ no, āvuso, kathan”ti?
9533.example_1: “Well now, venerables, how could there be such a declaration when these things are not attained?”

53064.comment:
openrouter: xiaomi/mimo-v2-flash:free
In the contextual sentence at SN12.68, 'musilo' is the nominative singular form, vocative would be 'musila'. The name belongs to a monk (masc) and is listed among names of monks.
53064.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca musilo āyasmā ca paviṭṭho āyasmā ca nārado āyasmā ca ānando kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
53064.example_1: At one time the venerables Musīla, Saviṭṭha, Nārada, and Ānanda were staying near Kosambī in Ghosita’s monastery.
